Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is a Category 1 responder as laid down by the Civil Contingencies Act 2004 and the Health and Social Care Act 2012, which underpins EPRR within health. Both Acts place EPRR duties on NHS Funded organisation.

Additionally, the NHS Standard Contract Service Conditions (SC30) requires providers of NHS Funded services to comply with EPRR Framework and other NHS England and NHS Improvement guidance 1.3. During times of severe pressure and when responding to Critical incidents, Business Continuity and Major Incidents, NHS organisations need structures which provide:
Clear leadership;
Accountable decision making; and
Accurate, up to date and far reaching communications

A key element which enables the delivery of an appropriate command and support structure is the Loggist, who will ensure the maintenance of appropriate, contemporaneous records and documentation of decisions made and actions taken during the incident.
Record keeping assists the decision-maker in reaching a reasoned, lawful and justifiable decision at the time of a significant / major incident.
Logs are important to the decision-making process and for their post-incident evidential value. They also allow for lessons learned and will benefit incident commanders in the future.
Scope

The purpose of this document is to give guidance to those who may be involved in the decision making processes, or as part of the Command and Control procedures during the response to a critical, business continuity or major incident.
To record accurately the decisions taken during a Critical / Business Continuity / major incident
To aid communication
To have accurate information in order to facilitate operational debrief
To provide a written record so as to establish continuity of events and to refresh the memory of individuals after the event.
Definitions
Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Duties within the Trust (Committees)
Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response Committee
The Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response Committee is responsible
for ensuring that plans are in place to:
Support the development and implementation of Emergency Planning and Resilience capabilities in preparation for an emergency situation
Ensure a Business Impact Analysis is completed for their Care Group / Division and specific service areas as deemed necessary
Ensure a Directorate Resilience Plan (including Emergency Planning and Business Continuity) is in place for their Care Group / Division, if required.
Chief Executive
The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust has in place effective arrangements to respond to an incident that has the potential to affect service provision
Deputy Chief Executive / Senior Responsible Officer (SRO)
The Deputy Chief Executive is the designated Senior Accountable Officer for
EEmergency Preparedness Resilience and Response, who is responsible for

ensuring that the MSE has a Major Incident Plan in place that will also link into the organisations arrangements for business continuity, that is built on the principles of risk assessment, co-operation with partners, emergency planning, communicating with the public and information sharing.
The role of the SRO, is to endorse assurance to the Board that the organisation is meeting its obligations with respect to EPRR and relevant statutory obligations
under the Civil Contingencies Act 2004 (CCA) and the Health and Social Care Act 2012. This will include assurance that the organisation has allocated appropriate
resources to meet the requirements.
The SRO will ensure that the Board receives regular reports, at least annually,
regarding EPRR including reports on exercises, training and testing undertaken by the Trust, and that appropriate resources are made available to allow the discharge of these responsibilities.
Head of Emergency Preparedness Resilience and Response

The Head of EPRR ensures that the organisation meets its statutory obligations under the CCA, the Health and Social Care Act and the NHS England Emergency Preparedness Framework 2015, and complies with all relevant Emergency preparedness, resilience and response guidance for the NHS, including non- statutory guidance that accompanies the CCA and also business continuity and resilience preparedness.
Loggists
Loggists have a role prescribed by legislation, and the role is governed by the Civil Contingencies Act 2004 (CCA) and is set out in detail in Chapter 4 of the Emergency Response and Recovery (ERR).
Logging

Good communication is at the heart of an effective response, and for this to happen organisations must have properly trained staff, able to document and relay information without delay, so that all responding agencies share a common picture of the situation. Effective emergency communication involves many information management activities.
Planning for emergency communications must therefore pay close attention to procedures, the language used, human factors and the skilled use of different communication media.
Loggists must aim to provide the right information at the right time in a format that they can understand, assimilate and act upon:
To capture decisions and rationale during an incident or emergency following best practice.
To log for an assigned individual
To aid the response to an incident or emergency
To support any future enquires which may occur
A Loggist is not:
A minute taker
A gopher or runner
The tea / coffee maker
Responsible for all decisions – makers logs
Responsible for logging all communications
Decision maker guidance
Record keeping assistants and Loggists assist the decision maker in reaching a reasoned, lawful and justifiable decision at the time of an incident.
Wherever the decision is later considered, in a public inquiry or a court of law, the judge will ask the same question:' did the decision maker at the time reach a reasonable decision?'

It may be months or years away when memories have faded. The decision-makers will have to account for their decisions and will need to explain the decision making process and the circumstances or context within which they took a decision. Failure to note this can result in hindsight distorting the decision making process. At its worst, a reasonable decision could later be seen to be unreasonable and viewed by a court as negligent or criminal.

To facilitate operational debriefing, good record-keeping allows lessons to be identified and made more widely available for the benefit of those who might be involved in future emergencies. Appropriate follow-up may also be required which may include the revision of plans, procedures, training and the testing of alternative approaches.
Best practice
Public Health England Best Practice rules are as follows:

The following rules apply to the completion of original notes and decision logs, designed to ensure that evidential records are able to withstand close scrutiny by an objective third party during an inquiry or investigation. Therefore handwritten notes must be clear, intelligible and accurate. Furthermore, correctly compiled notes defined against allegations of improper alterations, deletions or addition.
Format
Dates are to be recorded using the full DD/MM/YY format
Times are recorded using the 24 hour clock
Ensure that numbers and letters are written clearly, particular care should be exercised to differentiate zeros from O, the number 6 from the letter b and so on.
The use of acronyms and abbreviations must be supported by a glossary of terms or an explanation at the first use.
Exhibits are recorded using the initials of the person producing or introducing the exhibit.
Always use a Black Ball Point Pen to complete the decision logs. Annotations are to be written in Red ballpoint pen.
No elbows
Erasures, mistakes must be ruled through with a single line and initialled.
Leaves torn out, decision log pages are sequentially numbered.
Blank Spaces, the aim of this rule is to ensure that it is impossible to add anything once the log is complete. Therefore blank spaces must not be left:
Between words
Between lines, or
At either end of lines
Overwriting, overwriting to alter or correct any word, letter or number is forbidden. Writing between lines, you must not write between lines of writing.
Statements in direct speech, record all statements, questions and comments in direct speech.
Jargon and acronyms
Wherever possible avoid using jargon or acronyms
Include a glossary of terms in your log
Clarify any jargon or acronyms you don't understand before you write it in the log
Reflective summary
Undertaken before sign off of the log/ during a period of review
Review decisions and actions already noted in the log
Add in any new decisions and actions that now need to be taken
Signing off the log
Review and sign off of the log is undertaken by the Incident Commander / Decision maker and Loggist
Ensuring actions and decisions have been recorded correctly
Ensure that acronyms/jargon explained or referenced with annotations
Blank spaces are lined through
Both the loggist and decision maker must sign and date the log, indicating its accuracy
Virtual logging procedure

It is considered best practise for incident logs to be recorded by ink and paper (non- volatile media), logged at the time, checked as an accurate account and signed off by both the loggist and decision maker. This will normally entail the Incident Management Team (IMT) including the loggist being located in the same Incident Co-ordination Centre (ICC).
It is acknowledged that there may be times where this is not always possible, for example a prolonged incident or adverse weather.
Should this occur the options below may be used/adapted:
The decision maker and the loggist being in a room together, with the rest of the meeting participants being virtual. The log book is then passed between the decision maker and loggist.
The decision maker maintains their own log alongside the notes. The decision maker must be familiar with best practice in decision logging for this to work
The meeting is conducted virtually and the loggist maintains the log virtually either electronically or in writing. The loggist can either:
Maintain a contemporaneous electronic record and have it signed off digitally by the decision maker (please see process below)
Have a log book wherever they are and send a scan to the decision maker to sign off.

It must be noted that both options above risk losing the contemporaneous nature of the log and open the log up to accusations of improper alteration should there be contradictory evidence. Therefore it is recommended that the decision rationale as to why the meeting is being held totally virtually is recorded at the start of the meeting.
Electronic record process with digital sign off
Complete the operational log, as at appendix 2, with all the usual logging rules being applied.
Sequence (item) numbers should start at V001.
The log should start an entry recording the rationale on why the decision was made to log virtually, example below;
Gold confirmed virtual logging in place due to significant snow fall and staff not able to attend the ICC safely.

At the end of logging the loggist will include their electronic signature, save the log as a pdf document and then send to the decision maker for approval. See appendix 3 for electronic signature process.
The document should be named as follows
Gold Log_date_time_loggist initials
The decision maker will review and if agrees with the log will insert their electronic signature and send to each sites incident control email address, EPRR lead and the loggist.
If amendments are required the decision maker will email the required changes to the loggist.
The loggist will make the necessary changes ‘in red' and send back the amended log to the decision maker for approval. Once agreed log is to be sent to incident control and the EPRR lead.
The amended log should be names as follows
Gold_Log_date_time_loggist initials_amended_date_time
Copies of both the original and amended log should be sent to the relevant incident email addresses
A copy of the completed log can be shared with the following loggist for reference.
Incident control will print a copy and insert into the appropriate logbook and retain an electronic copy of the log for future reference.
Records and record retention

Each sites incident Control Centres, contain hard bound Emergency Log Books 101 that have unique identification numbers printed on the covers they are specifically designed for the purpose of logging, each book must only be used for 1 incident, and then retained safely for a period of 30 years. It is the responsibility of the Trust's Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response leads to undertake the safe storage of these emergency log books.
Training requirements
Training is available as a free one day training course delivered by the Public Health England entitled ‘Logging the Vital Component of a Major Incident', or on- site training provided by EPRR leads.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by each sites Emergency Preparedness and Business Continuity Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Emergency Preparedness and Business Continuity Committee of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

Appendix 1: Loggist action card and notes

table_items.text: Trust sites individual Incident Control Centre (unless advised otherwise)

You will help to set up the incident control room, perform the logging of information, decisions and actions (IDAs) as required by the Incident Control Team and ensure a record / log of the incident is maintained.

Proceed to the Incident Control Room as directed. Report to the Strategic/Tactical / Operational Incident Manager Assist in setting up the Incident Control Room with telephones, computers etc. Maintain a log of information, decisions, communications, and actions taken by the incident control team. NB. The record must be made in permanent black ink, clearly written, dated and initialled by the loggist at start of shift. All persons in attendance to be recorded in the log. The log must be a complete and continuous (chronological) record of all issues/ options considered / decisions along with reasoning behind those decisions /actions. Timings have to be accurate and recorded each time information is received or transmitted. If individuals are tasked with a function or role this must be documented and when the task is completed this must also be documented.
Provide support services as directed. All documentation is to be kept safe and retained for evidence for any future proceedings

Participate in a “hot” de-brief immediately after the incident and any subsequent structured de-brief. Following stand-down evaluate admin effectiveness and any lessons learned and report these to the Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response leads for inclusion in the post incident report.

Appendix 3: Virtual log book sign off
To sign a document using Adobe Reader, first open the PDF document and click the “Fill & Sign” button in the right pane.
Click the “Sign” button on the toolbar and select “Add Signature” to add your signature

You can create a signature in one of three ways. By default, Adobe Reader selects “Type” so you can type your name and have it converted to a signature. This won't look like your real signature, so it probably isn't ideal.

Select “Draw” and then draw your signature using your mouse or a touch screen. You can also select “Image” if you'd like to sign a piece of paper, scan it with a scanner, and then add your written signature to Adobe Reader.
After creating a signature, click “Apply” to apply it to the document. Leave “Save Signature” checked and you can quickly add this signature in the future.
Position your signature where you want it with your mouse and click to apply it. If you chose to save your signature, you'll find it easily accessible in the “Sign” menu in the future.
To save your signed PDF document, click File > Save and select a location for the file.
